data.title: addSelectionToNextFindMatch doesn't work with multiple cursors

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have three rows with a string in them.
2. hold alt, click before the first character of every word.
3. activate addSelectionToNextFindMatch, I have sublime-keymap, so that's ctrl+d for me.
4. only the last word will be selected.

data.title: No display scaling for Release Notes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:31:00.827Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.0.18|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.8|
|beautify|HookyQR|0.7.3|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.6.2|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.9.0|

---

On Windows 10, using DPI scaling (at 175%), opening VSCode after updating it to the latest version for the first time, the Release Notes tab appears automatically, but the content inside the tab is not scaled to fit the window.  It appears to be sized as if DPI scaling was at 100%.

data.title: TextEditor should expose EndOfLine setting
data.body: There is no way for an extension to learn the current EndOfLine setting in the VS Code Editor. This seems like it should be a property exposed by the TextEditor interface.

data.title: Copy formatted code to clipboard
data.body:
#3518.

Users are asking for this feature for a while and now it's the time to make it happen as @alexandrudima 's tokenization and syntax highlighting improvement https://code.visualstudio.com/blogs/2017/02/08/syntax-highlighting-optimizations makes everything easy.

Before his smart refactor, whenever we open an ordinary source code file, we have tens of CSS Class for each token and view line and we put like around hundreds of CSS entries in the output HTML. In this situation, if we want to send the formatted code or HTML snippet to the clipboard and makes it look reasonable, we have to do one of the followings

1. Append the generated CSS rules from Theme to the HTML Dom elements of selected content and send them all to the clipboard. Even if you just select a few characters, we still have to put all the CSS rules in the payload. I know there must be some way to filter the CSS rules and reduce them as few as possible but it'll be real pain.
2. Translate all the CSS Classes an element has to final styles, eg, `token meta function js definition parameters punctuation` to `color: #ffffff`. This one looks more reasonable but it requires a good engine to take care of the CSS rules.

At this moment, Alex already did all the complex CSS calculation for us in the improvement I mentioned above, the drawbacks of #1 and #2 are already gone now. For #1, we reduced the amount of CSS rules to 10 or 20 in most cases so the payload is not that giant. For #2, since the whole theme/tokenization engine is based on colors directly instead of CSS Classes, we just need to read the color from memory.

#2 is a better approach but as a POC, I still pick #2 then I can keep the code change minimal.

## Performance
We are not relying on the browser(Chrome) to handle the copy/paste as we can't guarantee that content users select in the editor exist in the DOM tree. This is because we only render content that are visible to users for the sake of performance. If users select content out of the viewport then we have to pay the price of rendering the invisible part to get the DOM elements with styles.

You can imagine the worst case is that ppl open a large file and copy the whole content. As most of the lines are invisible and we have to render all of them when copying, it's very likely to see lagging. So I tested against the three files Alex played with in https://code.visualstudio.com/blogs/2017/02/08/syntax-highlighting-optimizations#_tokenization-times on my powerfull MacBook Pro (Retina, 15-inch, Mid 2015, 2.2 GHz Intel Core i7)


| File        | Size           | Time of copying with rich text  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
| checker.ts      | 1.18 MB | 670ms |
| bootstrap.min.css      | 118.36 KB | 55ms |
| sqlite3.c	      | 6.73 MB	 | 3100ms |

`bootstrap.min.css` is good, `checker.ts`'s lag is noticeable and `sqlite3.c` is bad. But `sqlite3.c` is unusual and I bet you don't want to copy the content from Code and paste it to other applications. On my lovely machine, pasting the 6.73 MB content to Word takes **9 minutes**.

`checker.ts` is not an usual case I suppose as it has 22000+ lines and copying the whole content and pasting doesn't always happen. But I still put this feature behind a boolean option and set its default value as false to avoid annoying most users who don't necessarily need it.

## TODO
- [x] [We do] Investigate whether we should switch to #1 as not all applications honor `<style>` tag in HTML entry in the clipboard. Word loves it but Evernote just ignores this element. Besides, browsers will transform all the classes to inline styles when you copy the content on a webpage, so maybe we should do the same thing. It requires some tweaks on `renderViewLine`.
- [x] IE only support setting `Text` and `URL ` to the clipboard, `HTML` is not supported according to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms536744(v=vs.85).aspx
- [x] Add a separate command for copy large files

data.title: Allow extensions to define the editor layout
data.body:
Hello,

When I'm using the MSSQL extension and execute a query, it spits the window into two side by side panels to show the results. I can change that to over and under by toggling the editor layout, but I can't seem to find a setting that allows me to change the default. It would be nice for it to always open over and under.

If I haven't missed an existing global setting, I'd be happy just with that being added. However, what would really be nice is to have setting specific to certain actions. For example, I like seeing diff's side by side. I'd prefer to keep that, and still get SQL results over and under. Do extension developers have the ability to specify how the editor will split when they call for it? That would be ideal, then I'd ask that extension to make a setting too.

Thanks,
Stephen

data.title: Intellisense derived from JSDoc does not function correctly when imported
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

When using an ES2015 class as a type in JSDoc it does not appear to work correctly in files that import that class via a require statement.

While working within the same file that the class was defined in, everything works as expected. (shown below).

![An example of JSDoc typing working correctly in the same file](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4516547/22762823/62edaf00-eeb5-11e6-8dd9-363acae1b28c.jpg)

While working within a different file the class appears to import correctly and show its constructor typing (shown below).

![An example of an imported class working correctly](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4516547/22762822/62ed0028-eeb5-11e6-858c-c0f7a52054e8.jpg)

But when I try to use the class for typing (As done in the first image) it no longer considers my class as a valid type.

![An example of an imported class not being accepted as a type](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4516547/22762824/62eeb706-eeb5-11e6-88ec-de5d2dedb1bd.png)

Here is the jsconfig I was using for this example

```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es6",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true
    }
}
```

Apologies if this has been submitted before. I couldn't seem to find it in the issue search.

data.title: Allow MarkedStrings in Diagnostics
data.body: It would be nice to be able to include markdown (such as url links) inside of Diagnostics. That way you could provide a url where a user could go to see more information about a particular error or warning. This functionality currently exists in Hover, so I would think it wouldn't be a big deal to do it for Diagnostics too.

data.title: VS Code complains about lack of internet

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:23:30.856Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|sublime-commands|Zarel|0.1.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code
2. Wait a day or so, while switching between various low-quality internet connections 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/551184/22759733/2628fdbe-ee19-11e6-8553-9330e0828e54.png)

Now, I'm aware that VS Code uses the internet for various features, including checking for updates and running `git fetch` on startup (or intermittently? not exactly sure when exactly it runs `git fetch`).

But VS Code should not require an internet connection unless I'm doing something like browsing the extension store, and it should not complain about lacking an internet connection while I'm doing literally nothing except leaving it open.

These errors are also kind of frustrating since they're not even telling me what VS is doing that needs an internet connection. A good error message tells me what failed and ideally how to fix it. The first two don't even tell me why I'm supposed to care that I don't have an internet connection, and the third doesn't tell me anything about what request it was or why it's initiating requests.

Like, I don't mind tracking; I opt-into all tracking so it might have been something like that. Just don't show me error messages when your tracking fails; that's your problem, not mine.

data.title: Key binding to quick open in new split
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

When using `ctrl`+`p` I can search for a file and hit enter to open it *OR* use the little icon to open the new file in a split.

Ideally I would be able to use the `ctrl`+`\` binding to open in a new split from the quick find, or is this already possible with another key binding I was unable to find?

Cheers.
